SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian, a 58-year-old male with a past medical history of congestive heart failure and hypertension, presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He also experiences shortness of breath when exerting energy. He denies fever, chills, and chest pain but reports a slight cough. Brian has been taking his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Congestive heart failure
Hypertension

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily
Lasix (to be increased to 80 mg daily)

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.

Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm. 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory: Fine crackles at lung bases bilaterally.

Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs, suggestive of heart failure.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT

1. Congestive heart failure with fluid retention.
2. Hypertension, well-managed at this time.

PLAN

1. Increase Lasix to 80 mg once daily.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
3. Weigh daily and report weight gain or shortness of breath.
4. Record blood pressures at home and report elevated readings.
5. Order an echocardiogram.
6. Follow up after test results are received.

INSTRUCTIONS

Increase Lasix dosage, continue monitoring blood pressure and weight, and report any concerning symptoms. Schedule an echocardiogram and follow up after results are received.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Raymond Taylor is a 43-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for right knee pain. The patient reports that he was changing a light bulb on a ladder when he stumbled and twisted his knee while trying to catch his fall. The incident occurred yesterday. The pain is located on the inside of his knee. He has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

MEDICATIONS

Digoxin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for any other pain or symptoms.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Knee: Tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress. Normal sensation. No pain in the calves.

X-RAY

No fractures or dislocations. Proper alignment. Some fluid present.

ASSESSMENT

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain of the right knee.

PLAN

1. Prescribe a knee brace and crutches for temporary use.
2. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 week. If no improvement, consider an MRI.
3. Prescribe Motrin 800 mg every 6 hours with food for 2 weeks.
4. Order medications and procedures discussed, and finalize the report.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The onset of his pain began 7 days ago when he was lifting heavy boxes while helping his daughter. He reports hearing a pop and experiencing pain in his lower back. He has been using ice, an ACE wrap, and taking Tylenol and ibuprofen for pain management.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient enjoys playing basketball and spending time with his family.

MEDICATIONS

The patient takes metformin 500 mg twice a day for diabetes and lisinopril 10 mg daily for hypertension.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports lower back pain and stiffness. Denies any numbness or tingling in legs.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the back reveals pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, and a negative straight leg raise test.

RESULTS

Back X-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fractures present.

Hemoglobin A1c: 8, elevated.

ASSESSMENT

1. Lower back pain, likely lumbar strain.
2. Diabetes type 2, slightly uncontrolled.
3. Hypertension, needs better control.
4. Osteoarthritis, stable.

PLAN

1. For lower back pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.
2. For diabetes, increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day and repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
3. For hypertension, increase lisinopril to 20 mg daily.
4. For osteoarthritis, continue monitoring and managing symptoms as needed.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 7 days to check on his progress. If his back pain has not improved, further evaluation may be considered. The patient should continue to monitor his blood sugars and blood pressure regularly.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. John Perry is a 61-year-old male with a past medical history significant for kidney stones, migraines, and gastroesophageal reflux, who presents with back pain. The patient reports experiencing pain similar to his previous kidney stone pain. The pain started on the right side and moved to the left side of his back, lasting for the past 4 days. Initially, the pain was intermittent, but it has been constant for the last 48 hours. Tylenol has not provided relief. The patient suspects hematuria, but it is difficult to confirm. He experiences nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and lightheadedness with exertion. 

Regarding his migraines, the patient has been compliant with Imitrex and reports no issues. For his gastroesophageal reflux, the patient has been managing his diet well, although he has been consuming more fast food and takeout recently due to his pain. He is staying hydrated and taking Protonix 40 mg daily as directed.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: Endorses abdominal pain. Endorses nausea and vomiting with exertion.
• Genitourinary: Endorses urine discoloration.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Endorses body aches.
• Neurological: Denies headaches. Endorses dizziness and lightheadedness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant. CVA tenderness on the right.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated.

RESULTS

Creatinine level slightly elevated.
Abdominal x-ray demonstrates possible kidney stone.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. John Perry is a 61-year-old male with a past medical history significant for kidney stones, migraines, and gastroesophageal reflux, who presents with back pain.

Kidney stones.
• Medical Reasoning: He is experiencing pain in his back that is similar to his previous kidney stone pain. His recent abdominal x-ray demonstrates what appears to be a recurrent kidney stone.
• Additional Testing: I have ordered a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast.
• Medical Treatment: We will start him on Ultram 50 mg as needed every 6 hours for pain.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to stay well hydrated and to strain his urine.

Migraines.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with Imitrex and is doing well at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Imitrex.

Reflux.
• Medical Reasoning: This is typically well-controlled with dietary modifications.
• Medical Treatment: Continue with Protonix 40 mg daily. A refill was provided.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Raymond Taylor is a 48-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for right finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and experienced an injury to her right finger while going over moguls. She states that her finger was bent backward during the incident. The injury occurred four days ago.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Constipation, appendectomy at age 18.

MEDICATIONS

Miralax for constipation.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right finger pain and tenderness.
Gastrointestinal: Reports constipation.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion. Normal range of motion.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right hand: No fractures identified. Normal alignment.

ASSESSMENT

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN

1. Prescribe aluminum foam splint for the right index finger.
2. Prescribe Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for pain relief, to be taken for one week.
3. Follow-up in one week if symptoms do not improve.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in one week if symptoms do not improve.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Alan Mitchell is a 69-year-old male presenting with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. The patient denies any specific injury but has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. The pain is constant and primarily located in the left shoulder, without radiation down the arm. The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. He also experiences difficulty sleeping due to the pain. The patient has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He initially iced his shoulder but has not iced it recently. The patient denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain.
Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and worsening headaches.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Martha Collins is a 50-year-old female with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure, depression, and hypertension who presents for her annual exam. It has been a year since I last saw the patient.

The patient has been traveling a lot recently since things have gotten a bit better. She reports that she got her COVID-19 vaccine so she feels safer about traveling. She has been doing a lot of hiking.

She reports that she is staying active. She has continued watching her diet and she is doing well with that. The patient states that she is avoiding salty foods that she likes to eat. She has continued utilizing her medications. The patient denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, or swelling in her legs.

Regarding her depression, she reports that she has been going to therapy every week for the past year. This has been really helpful for her. She denies suicidal or homicidal ideation.

The patient reports that she is still forgetting to take her blood pressure medication. She has noticed that when work gets more stressful, her blood pressure goes up. She reports that work has been going okay, but it has been a lot of long hours lately.

She endorses some nasal congestion from some of the fall allergies. She denies any other symptoms of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from allergies.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression. Denies suicidal or homicidal ideations.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
1+ pitting edema of the bilateral lower extremities.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram demonstrates decreased ejection fraction of 45%. Mitral regurgitation is present.

Lipid panel: Elevated cholesterol.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Martha Collins is a 50-year-old female with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure, depression, and hypertension who presents for her annual exam.

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: She has been compliant with her medication and dietary modifications. Her previous year's echocardiogram demonstrated a reduced ejection fraction of 45%, as well as some mitral regurgitation. Her cholesterol levels were slightly elevated on her lipid panel from last year.
• Additional Testing: We will order a repeat echocardiogram. We will also repeat a lipid panel this year.
• Medical Treatment: She will continue with her current medications. We will increase her lisinopril to 40 mg daily and initiate Lasix 20 mg daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to continue with dietary modifications.

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: She is doing well with weekly therapy.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: She has been compliant with dietary modifications but has been inconsistent with the use of her medication. She attributes elevations in her blood pressure to increased stress.
• Medical Treatment: We will increase her lisinopril to 40 mg daily as noted above.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to take her lisinopril as directed. I advised her to monitor her blood pressures at home for the next week and report them to me.

Healthcare maintenance.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is due for her routine mammogram.
• Additional Testing: We will order a mammogram and have this scheduled for her.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 48-year-old female who presents for shortness of breath. She has a history of depression, smoking, and chronic back pain. She reports shortness of breath with mild exercise and walking, as well as palpitations. She has been exercising more and has reduced her smoking from two packs a day to a couple of cigarettes daily. Her depression is managed with Effexor, and her chronic back pain is managed with Neurontin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Endorses dyspnea on exertion and palpitations.
Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain.
Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Respiratory: Mild wheezes bilaterally.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Shortness of breath.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with shortness of breath, which may be related to her history of smoking and possible COPD. Her pulmonary function tests and chest x-ray are consistent with COPD.
- Medical Treatment: We will start the patient on Combivent, 2 puffs twice a day, albuterol inhaler, 2 puffs as needed, and a prednisone taper pack.

2. Depression.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's depression is stable on Effexor.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Effexor as prescribed.

3. Chronic back pain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well on Neurontin for her back pain.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Neurontin as prescribed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed for any additional episodes of pain or other symptoms. She will call the office if she has any concerns or needs to schedule an EGD.

Chief Complaint:

Smith-Magenis Syndrome evaluation.

History of Present Illness:

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned potential kidney issues associated with her syndrome.

Review of Systems:

GI: Reflux.
Musculoskeletal: Developmental delays, not walking independently yet.

Physical Exam:

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

Assessment:

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

Plan:

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
2. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.
3. If the ultrasound is abnormal, determine next steps and future follow-up at the town center location.

The family will be contacted with the results of the ultrasound and provided with further instructions based on the findings.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports falling while carrying a laundry basket down the stairs yesterday morning. She attempted to catch herself with her arms outstretched and subsequently experienced severe pain and swelling in her right wrist. She has tried ice, an ACE wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

PAST HISTORY

No prior injuries to the right arm.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional: Elderly female in apparent distress due to wrist pain.

Neurologic: No numbness or tingling reported in the fingers.

Musculoskeletal: Obvious swelling and ecchymosis in the right wrist. Tenderness on palpation throughout the wrist. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but unable to do so tightly.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

• Colles' fracture of the right wrist

PLAN

1. Apply a brace to the right wrist for support and immobilization.
2. Schedule surgery for the patient as soon as possible.
3. Prescribe 50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours for pain management.
4. Begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery, with an estimated frequency of three times per week.
5. Follow-up appointment in one month to assess progress and discuss the possibility of going on vacation.

This plan was discussed in detail with the patient, who is in agreement.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Wear the brace for six weeks.
2. Attend physical therapy as recommended.
3. Take Ultram as prescribed for pain management.
4. Schedule and attend surgery and follow-up appointments.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of hypertension.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Endorses shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain after a fall. Denies swelling or muscle pain.
Neurological: Denies dizziness or lightheadedness.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally.
Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee, pain with flexion and extension, edema around the knee, and effusion.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee pain (MCL strain).
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with right knee pain after a fall, with pain on the medial aspect of the knee and pain with flexion and extension.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day. Advise the patient to elevate and stay off the leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg of Lisinopril. Blood pressure was high during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Refer the patient to a nutritionist to help with diet management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan for their knee pain and hypertension. They should follow up if there are any concerns or if their symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a 57-year-old male who presents with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. He denies any specific injury but has been active and working in his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past but nothing that Tylenol couldn't take care of. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has difficulty sleeping on the affected shoulder.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None reported.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient is active and currently renovating his basement.

MEDICATIONS

Extra strength Tylenol as needed for pain.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.
Neurovascular: Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch.

RESULTS
Imaging

Left shoulder X-ray: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left shoulder pain - likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with a rotator cuff tendinopathy.
- Diagnostic Tests: Order an MRI of the left shoulder to further evaluate the rotator cuff and rule out other causes of pain.
- Treatment: Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks. Continue Tylenol as needed for pain. If symptoms do not improve, consider a steroid injection for the shoulder.
- Patient Education: Discuss the importance of physical therapy and strengthening exercises for the shoulder muscles to reduce reliance on the joints.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a 40-year-old female who presents with occasional left knee pain. The patient reports that the pain occurs less than once a day while walking, causing her knee to feel unstable and as if it might give out. She has not experienced any popping sensation or had any prior injuries to the knee. The pain is not severe enough to require medication and does not last long. The patient has an upcoming trip and is concerned about participating in activities such as line dancing due to her knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, diabetes mellitus.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, Farxiga.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2°F, pulse 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 122/70.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS
Imaging

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain: Suspect arthritis. Plan to prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.

2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.

3. Diabetes mellitus: Order hemoglobin A1c to assess need for adjustments to metformin dosage. Order lipid panel.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule an appointment for an echocardiogram. Call the clinic with any additional concerns or questions.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Shortness of breath, cough, and sore throat.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer who presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. The patient reports minimal cough and sore throat today, with no shortness of breath. She has been experiencing fatigue but denies nausea or vomiting.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Positive for cough and sore throat. Negative for shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Negative for nausea or vomiting.
General: Positive for fatigue.

VITALS

Vitals are stable, including oxygen saturation.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Crackles bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest.
Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer: Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (4 times a day) to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient education and counseling provided regarding treatment plan and potential side effects. The patient agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. Follow-up scheduled for the next visit.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right eye twitch.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Karen Nelson is a 3-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of a new right eye twitch. The onset of her twitch began a couple of weeks ago, as noticed by her father. Karen reports feeling her face twitching but denies any pain associated with it. She states that she sometimes feels the urge to move her face, and it moves, providing relief. The frequency of the twitch varies, with some days having several occurrences per hour and other days having fewer instances.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of seizures or Tourette's syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Neurological: Denies numbness or loss of sensation.
Eyes: Reports right eye twitch.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological: Patient is alert and oriented. Speech is clear and fluent. Gait is steady. Cranial nerves grossly intact without focal neurologic findings. No pronator drift. Sensation is intact. Reflexes are 2+ and symmetric at the biceps, triceps, knees, and ankles.

ASSESSMENT

Right eye twitch, consistent with transient tic.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's history and physical examination, it is determined that Karen is experiencing a transient tic. The patient and her father were educated on the nature of the diagnosis and advised that tics are common in children, often resolving on their own within a year. It was recommended to avoid drawing attention to the tic, as it may cause Karen to feel self-conscious and increase the severity of the tic. No further treatment is recommended at this time, but the patient and her father were advised to monitor for any worsening of symptoms or changes in Karen's overall health.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence Smith is a pleasant 45-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right elbow pain. He reports an onset of approximately 4 days ago but denies any specific injury. The patient notes that he has recently been engaging in pottery and ceramics, which involves repetitive motions. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and occasionally radiates down into his forearm. He rates the pain as a 6 out of 10 and states that it interferes with his daily activities and keeps him up at night. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient denies any previous injuries to the right elbow.

SOCIAL HISTORY

He reports engaging in pottery and ceramics as a hobby during the pandemic.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain. Denies left elbow pain.
Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling in the arm.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the right elbow: Moderate tenderness to palpation over the medial epicondyle. Pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist. Pain with pronation of the right forearm.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality noted.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis (right elbow).

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's clinical history and examination today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding treatment options for his current symptoms. I advised the patient to rest his right elbow and provided him with a sling to wear while awake. I recommended applying ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and taking ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. I also advised the patient to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks to allow for healing. The patient will follow up with me in 1 week to assess his progress and discuss further treatment options if necessary.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension, recent fall, and chest pain.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports a sedentary lifestyle and poor diet, including salty foods.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc inconsistently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during exertion.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
Genitourinary: Denies polyuria.
Musculoskeletal: Reports trace edema in lower extremities.
Neurological: Denies lower extremity weakness or numbness.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 128/72

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advised the patient to monitor their weight daily and follow a low-salt diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily. Consult with a nutritionist.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Uncontrolled hypertension contributing to CHF.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to take medications consistently and monitor blood pressure at home.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg daily. Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up with a nutritionist and monitor weight and blood pressure daily.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who has been experiencing sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain comes and goes and is severe when present. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Russell has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them in the past.

FAMILY HISTORY

The patient's father has a history of kidney stones.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen shows a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone)
- Medical Treatment: Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, alternating with Tylenol. Provide a strainer for urine collection to monitor stone passage.
- Diagnostic Tests: Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
- Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Nicholas is a diabetic patient who presents today with a non-healing foot ulcer on his right foot. He first noticed the ulcer about six weeks ago after wearing a pair of tight shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister, which later unroofed and developed a foul smell with yellow drainage. The patient's wife noticed a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is also hot to touch. The patient has been on antibiotics for six days and has experienced some improvement, but the wound has turned black around the edges, and he has been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. The patient also reports difficulty catching his breath and increased coughing over the last two days.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes mellitus with diabetic neuropathy. The patient's blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range over the last two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His A1C is 6.7.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer with cellulitis and possible infection.

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement of the wound in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on culture results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's calf closely.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to maintain optimal blood sugar control.

INSTRUCTIONS

- Continue the current antibiotic therapy as prescribed by the primary care physician.
- Follow up with the endocrinologist to maintain optimal blood sugar control.
- Return in 7 days for a follow-up appointment.
- Call with any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a male patient who presents with a tick bite on his right knee. He is unsure of when or where he got the tick bite but mentions spending time outdoors and going hunting recently. The tick bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. He has not experienced any fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite. He denies any joint pain or difficulty moving his knee.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.
Diabetes.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril.
Metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs
Blood pressure: 122/70.
Heart rate: 67.
Temperature: 98.4.

Cardiovascular
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.

Respiratory
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
Right knee: Erythema, edema, area of fluctuance over right patella, pain to palpation, full range of motion.

Skin
Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes.

PLAN

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease:
   - Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 3 weeks.
   - Order Lyme titer and Western blot tests.
   - Monitor response to treatment and consider IV antibiotics if needed.

2. Hypertension:
   - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg once a day.
   - Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes:
   - Order hemoglobin A1c test.
   - Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice a day.
   - Monitor blood sugar levels and adjust treatment as needed.

4. Kidney function:
   - Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up with results of blood tests and monitor response to doxycycline treatment. Call clinic with any additional concerns or worsening symptoms.
